text: General elections were held in Sweden on 19 September 1948.Nohlen, D & Stöver, P (2010) Elections in Europe: A data handbook, p1858 Despite a campaign by a large part of the Swedish press against socializing insurances, controlled foreign trade and rationing regulations still in use since the war, freshman Prime Minister and Social Democratic leader Tage Erlander managed to defeat the People's Party-led opposition under Bertil Ohlin by a higher election turnout. He maintained his government with only minor losses and the Swedish Social Democratic Party remained the largest party, winning 112 of the 230 seats in the Second Chamber of the Riksdag. Erlander was later to stay on as Prime Minister until 1969, in 1951-1957 his government included the party Farmers' League.Nohlen & Stöver, p1872 ==Results== {| class=wikitable style=text-align:right |- |colspan=7|300px |- !Party !Votes !% !Seats !+/– |- |align=left|Social Democratic Party||1,789,459||46.1||112||–3 |- |align=left|People's Party||882,437||22.7||57||+31 |- |align=left|Farmers' League||480,421||12.4||30||–5 |- |align=left|National Organisation of the Right||478,786||12.3||23||–16 |- |align=left|Communist Party||244,826||6.3||8||–7 |- |align=left|Other parties||3,062||0.1||0||0 |- |align=left|Invalid/blank votes||16,170||–||–||– |- |align=left|Total||3,895,161||100||230||0 |- |align=left|Registered voters/turnout||4,707,783||82.7||–||– |- |align=left colspan=5|Source: Nohlen & Stöver |} ==References== 1948 Category:1948 elections in Europe Category:1948 in Sweden Category:September 1948 events
title: 1948 Swedish general election
